trans-unit.source: App model v2.0 preview: Token reference
trans-unit.target: App model v2.0 preview: Token reference

trans-unit.source: The v2.0 endpoint emits several types of security tokens in the processing of each [authentication flow](active-directory-v2-flows.md).
trans-unit.target: The v2.0 endpoint emits several types of security tokens in the processing of each [authentication flow](active-directory-v2-flows.md).

trans-unit.source: This document describes the format, security characteristics, and contents of each type of token.
trans-unit.target: This document describes the format, security characteristics, and contents of each type of token.

trans-unit.source: This information applies to the v2.0 app model public preview.
trans-unit.target: This information applies to the v2.0 app model public preview.

trans-unit.source: For instructions on how to integrate with the generally available Azure AD service, please refer to the [Azure Active Directory Developer Guide](active-directory-developers-guide.md).
trans-unit.target: For instructions on how to integrate with the generally available Azure AD service, please refer to the [Azure Active Directory Developer Guide](active-directory-developers-guide.md).

trans-unit.source: Types of Tokens
trans-unit.target: Types of Tokens

trans-unit.source: The v2.0 endpoint supports the [OAuth 2.0 authorization protocol](active-directory-v2-protocols.md), which makes use of both access_tokens and refresh_tokens.
trans-unit.target: The v2.0 endpoint supports the [OAuth 2.0 authorization protocol](active-directory-v2-protocols.md), which makes use of both access_tokens and refresh_tokens.

trans-unit.source: It also supports authentication and sign-in via [OpenID Connect](active-directory-v2-protocols.md#openid-connect-sign-in-flow), which introduces a third type of token, the id_token.
trans-unit.target: It also supports authentication and sign-in via [OpenID Connect](active-directory-v2-protocols.md#openid-connect-sign-in-flow), which introduces a third type of token, the id_token.

trans-unit.source: Each of these tokens is represented as a "bearer token".
trans-unit.target: Each of these tokens is represented as a "bearer token".

trans-unit.source: A bearer token is a lightweight security token that grants the “bearer” access to a protected resource.
trans-unit.target: A bearer token is a lightweight security token that grants the “bearer” access to a protected resource.

trans-unit.source: In this sense, the “bearer” is any party that can present the token.
trans-unit.target: In this sense, the “bearer” is any party that can present the token.

trans-unit.source: Though a party must first authenticate with Azure AD to receive the bearer token, if the required steps are not taken to secure the token in transmission and storage, it can be intercepted and used by an unintended party.
trans-unit.target: Though a party must first authenticate with Azure AD to receive the bearer token, if the required steps are not taken to secure the token in transmission and storage, it can be intercepted and used by an unintended party.

trans-unit.source: While some security tokens have a built-in mechanism for preventing unauthorized parties from using them, bearer tokens do not have this mechanism and must be transported in a secure channel such as transport layer security (HTTPS).
trans-unit.target: While some security tokens have a built-in mechanism for preventing unauthorized parties from using them, bearer tokens do not have this mechanism and must be transported in a secure channel such as transport layer security (HTTPS).

trans-unit.source: If a bearer token is transmitted in the clear, a man-in the middle attack can be used by a malicious party to acquire the token and use it for an unauthorized access to a protected resource.
trans-unit.target: If a bearer token is transmitted in the clear, a man-in the middle attack can be used by a malicious party to acquire the token and use it for an unauthorized access to a protected resource.

trans-unit.source: The same security principles apply when storing or caching bearer tokens for later use.
trans-unit.target: The same security principles apply when storing or caching bearer tokens for later use.

trans-unit.source: Always ensure that your app transmits and stores bearer tokens in a secure manner.
trans-unit.target: Always ensure that your app transmits and stores bearer tokens in a secure manner.

trans-unit.source: For more security considerations on bearer tokens, see [RFC 6750 Section 5](http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6750).
trans-unit.target: For more security considerations on bearer tokens, see [RFC 6750 Section 5](http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6750).

trans-unit.source: Many of the tokens issued by the v2.0 endpoint are implemented as Json Web Tokens, or JWTs.
trans-unit.target: Many of the tokens issued by the v2.0 endpoint are implemented as Json Web Tokens, or JWTs.

trans-unit.source: A JWT is a compact, URL-safe means of transferring information between two parties.
trans-unit.target: A JWT is a compact, URL-safe means of transferring information between two parties.

trans-unit.source: The information contained in JWTs are known as "claims", or assertions of information about the bearer and subject of the token.
trans-unit.target: The information contained in JWTs are known as "claims", or assertions of information about the bearer and subject of the token.

trans-unit.source: The claims in JWTs are JSON objects encoded and serialized for transmission.
trans-unit.target: The claims in JWTs are JSON objects encoded and serialized for transmission.

trans-unit.source: Since the JWTs issued by the v2.0 endpoint are signed, but not encrypted, you can easily inspect the contents of a JWT for debugging purposes.
trans-unit.target: Since the JWTs issued by the v2.0 endpoint are signed, but not encrypted, you can easily inspect the contents of a JWT for debugging purposes.

trans-unit.source: There are several tools available for doing so, such as [calebb.net](https://calebb.net).
trans-unit.target: There are several tools available for doing so, such as [calebb.net](https://calebb.net).

trans-unit.source: For more information on JWTs, you can refer to the [JWT specification](http://self-issued.info/docs/draft-ietf-oauth-json-web-token.html).
trans-unit.target: For more information on JWTs, you can refer to the [JWT specification](http://self-issued.info/docs/draft-ietf-oauth-json-web-token.html).

trans-unit.source: Id_Tokens
trans-unit.target: Id_Tokens

trans-unit.source: Id_tokens are a form of sign-in security token that your app receives when performing authentication using [OpenID Connect](active-directory-v2-protocols.md#openid-connect-sign-in-flow).
trans-unit.target: Id_tokens are a form of sign-in security token that your app receives when performing authentication using [OpenID Connect](active-directory-v2-protocols.md#openid-connect-sign-in-flow).

trans-unit.source: They are represented as [JWTs](#types-of-tokens), and contain claims that you can use for signing the user into your app.
trans-unit.target: They are represented as [JWTs](#types-of-tokens), and contain claims that you can use for signing the user into your app.

trans-unit.source: You can use the claims in an id_token as you see fit - commonly they are used for displaying account information or making access control decisions in an app.
trans-unit.target: You can use the claims in an id_token as you see fit - commonly they are used for displaying account information or making access control decisions in an app.

trans-unit.source: The v2.0 endpoint only issues one type of id_token, which has a consistent set of claims regardless of the type of user that has signed in.
trans-unit.target: The v2.0 endpoint only issues one type of id_token, which has a consistent set of claims regardless of the type of user that has signed in.

trans-unit.source: That is to say that the format and content of the id_tokens will be the same for both personal Microsoft Account users and work or school accounts.
trans-unit.target: That is to say that the format and content of the id_tokens will be the same for both personal Microsoft Account users and work or school accounts.

trans-unit.source: Id_tokens are signed, but not encrypted at this time.
trans-unit.target: Id_tokens are signed, but not encrypted at this time.

trans-unit.source: When your app receives an id_token, it must [validate the signature](#validating-tokens) to prove the token's authenticity and validate a few claims in the token to prove its validity.
trans-unit.target: When your app receives an id_token, it must [validate the signature](#validating-tokens) to prove the token's authenticity and validate a few claims in the token to prove its validity.

trans-unit.source: The claims validated by an app vary depending on scenario requirements, but there are some [common claim validations](#validating-tokens) that your app must perform in every scenario.
trans-unit.target: The claims validated by an app vary depending on scenario requirements, but there are some [common claim validations](#validating-tokens) that your app must perform in every scenario.

trans-unit.source: Full details on the claims in id_tokens are provided below, as well as a sample id_token.
trans-unit.target: Full details on the claims in id_tokens are provided below, as well as a sample id_token.

trans-unit.source: Note that the claims in id_tokens are not returned in any particular order.
trans-unit.target: Note that the claims in id_tokens are not returned in any particular order.

trans-unit.source: In addition, new claims can be introduced into id_tokens at any point in time - your app should not break as new claims are introduced.
trans-unit.target: In addition, new claims can be introduced into id_tokens at any point in time - your app should not break as new claims are introduced.

trans-unit.source: Access Tokens
trans-unit.target: Access Tokens

trans-unit.source: Access tokens issued by the v2.0 endpoint take two different formats.
trans-unit.target: Access tokens issued by the v2.0 endpoint take two different formats.

trans-unit.source: Access tokens that are issued on behalf of work or school accounts are JWTs, similar to an id_token.
trans-unit.target: Access tokens that are issued on behalf of work or school accounts are JWTs, similar to an id_token.

trans-unit.source: Access tokens that are issued on behalf of a personal Microsoft account are in a format known as "compact tickets".
trans-unit.target: Access tokens that are issued on behalf of a personal Microsoft account are in a format known as "compact tickets".

trans-unit.source: For this reason, in development you may notice a different string format for access tokens issued by the v2.0 endpoint.
trans-unit.target: For this reason, in development you may notice a different string format for access tokens issued by the v2.0 endpoint.

trans-unit.source: Over time, this difference in access tokens will be eliminated from the v2.0 endpoint.
trans-unit.target: Over time, this difference in access tokens will be eliminated from the v2.0 endpoint.

trans-unit.source: With that said, access tokens issued by the v2.0 endpoint are only consumable by Microsoft Services at this point in time.
trans-unit.target: With that said, access tokens issued by the v2.0 endpoint are only consumable by Microsoft Services at this point in time.

trans-unit.source: Your apps should not need to perform any validation or inspection of access tokens for any of the currently supported scenarios.
trans-unit.target: Your apps should not need to perform any validation or inspection of access tokens for any of the currently supported scenarios.

trans-unit.source: You can treat access tokens as completely opaque - they are just strings which your app can pass to Microsoft in HTTP requests.
trans-unit.target: You can treat access tokens as completely opaque - they are just strings which your app can pass to Microsoft in HTTP requests.

trans-unit.source: In the near future, the v2.0 endpoint will introduce the ability for your app to receive access tokens from other clients.
trans-unit.target: In the near future, the v2.0 endpoint will introduce the ability for your app to receive access tokens from other clients.

trans-unit.source: At that time, this information will be updated with the information your app needs to perform access token validation and other similar tasks.
trans-unit.target: At that time, this information will be updated with the information your app needs to perform access token validation and other similar tasks.

trans-unit.source: When you request an access token from the v2.0 endpoint, the v2.0 endpoint also returns some metadata about the access token for your app's consumption.
trans-unit.target: When you request an access token from the v2.0 endpoint, the v2.0 endpoint also returns some metadata about the access token for your app's consumption.

trans-unit.source: This information includes the expiry time of the access token and the scopes for which it is valid.
trans-unit.target: This information includes the expiry time of the access token and the scopes for which it is valid.

trans-unit.source: This allows your app to perform intelligent caching of access tokens without having to parse open the access token itself.
trans-unit.target: This allows your app to perform intelligent caching of access tokens without having to parse open the access token itself.

trans-unit.source: Refresh Tokens
trans-unit.target: Refresh Tokens

trans-unit.source: Refresh tokens are security tokens which your app can use to acquire new access tokens in an OAuth 2.0 flow.
trans-unit.target: Refresh tokens are security tokens which your app can use to acquire new access tokens in an OAuth 2.0 flow.

trans-unit.source: It allows your app to achieve long-term access to resources on behalf of a user without requiring interaction by the user.
trans-unit.target: It allows your app to achieve long-term access to resources on behalf of a user without requiring interaction by the user.

trans-unit.source: Refresh tokens are multi-resource.
trans-unit.target: Refresh tokens are multi-resource.

trans-unit.source: That is to say that a refresh token received during a token request for one resource can be redeemed for access tokens to a completely different resource.
trans-unit.target: That is to say that a refresh token received during a token request for one resource can be redeemed for access tokens to a completely different resource.

trans-unit.source: In order to receive a refresh in a token response, your app must request & be granted the `offline_acesss` scope.
trans-unit.target: In order to receive a refresh in a token response, your app must request & be granted the `offline_acesss` scope.

trans-unit.source: To learn more about the `offline_access` scope, refer to the [consent & scopes article here](active-directory-v2-scopes.md).
trans-unit.target: To learn more about the `offline_access` scope, refer to the [consent & scopes article here](active-directory-v2-scopes.md).

trans-unit.source: Refresh tokens are, and will always be, completely opaque to your app.
trans-unit.target: Refresh tokens are, and will always be, completely opaque to your app.

trans-unit.source: They are issued by the Azure AD v2.0 endpoint and can only be inspected & interpreted by the v2.0 endpoint.
trans-unit.target: They are issued by the Azure AD v2.0 endpoint and can only be inspected & interpreted by the v2.0 endpoint.

trans-unit.source: They are long-lived, but your app should not be written to expect that a refresh token will last for any period of time.
trans-unit.target: They are long-lived, but your app should not be written to expect that a refresh token will last for any period of time.

trans-unit.source: Refresh tokens can be invalidated at any moment in time for a variety of reasons.
trans-unit.target: Refresh tokens can be invalidated at any moment in time for a variety of reasons.

trans-unit.source: The only way for your app to know if a refresh token is valid is to attempt to redeem it by making a token request to the v2.0 endpoint.
trans-unit.target: The only way for your app to know if a refresh token is valid is to attempt to redeem it by making a token request to the v2.0 endpoint.

trans-unit.source: When you redeem a refresh token for a new access token (and if your app had been granted the `offline_access` scope), you will receive a new refresh token in the token response.
trans-unit.target: When you redeem a refresh token for a new access token (and if your app had been granted the `offline_access` scope), you will receive a new refresh token in the token response.

trans-unit.source: You should save the newly issued refresh token, replacing the one you used in the request.
trans-unit.target: You should save the newly issued refresh token, replacing the one you used in the request.

trans-unit.source: This will guarantee that your refresh tokens remain valid for as long as possible.
trans-unit.target: This will guarantee that your refresh tokens remain valid for as long as possible.

trans-unit.source: Validating Tokens
trans-unit.target: Validating Tokens

trans-unit.source: At this point in time, the only token validation your apps should need to perform is validating id_tokens.
trans-unit.target: At this point in time, the only token validation your apps should need to perform is validating id_tokens.

trans-unit.source: In order to validate an id_token, your app should validate both the id_token's signature and the claims in the id_token.
trans-unit.target: In order to validate an id_token, your app should validate both the id_token's signature and the claims in the id_token.

trans-unit.source: We provide libraries & code samples that show how to easily handle token validation - the below information is simply provided for those who wish to understand the underlying process.
trans-unit.target: We provide libraries & code samples that show how to easily handle token validation - the below information is simply provided for those who wish to understand the underlying process.

trans-unit.source: There are also several 3rd party open source libraries available for JWT validation - there is at least one option for almost every platform & language out there.
trans-unit.target: There are also several 3rd party open source libraries available for JWT validation - there is at least one option for almost every platform & language out there.

trans-unit.source: Validating the Signature A JWT contains three segments, which are separated by the `.` character.
trans-unit.target: Validating the Signature A JWT contains three segments, which are separated by the `.` character.

trans-unit.source: The first segment is known as the **header**, the second as the **body**, and the third as the **signature**.
trans-unit.target: The first segment is known as the **header**, the second as the **body**, and the third as the **signature**.

trans-unit.source: The signature segment can be used to validate the authenticity of the id_token so that it can be trusted by your app.
trans-unit.target: The signature segment can be used to validate the authenticity of the id_token so that it can be trusted by your app.

trans-unit.source: Id_Tokens are signed using industry standard asymmetric encryption algorithms, such as RSA 256.
trans-unit.target: Id_Tokens are signed using industry standard asymmetric encryption algorithms, such as RSA 256.

trans-unit.source:
The header of the id_token contains information about the key and encryption method used to sign the token:
``` { typ: "JWT", alg: "RS256", x5t: "GvnPApfWMdLRi8PDmisFn7bprKg" } ```
The `alg` claim indicates the algorithm that was used to sign the token, while the `kid` or `x5t` claims indicate the particular public key that was used to sign the token.
trans-unit.target:
The header of the id_token contains information about the key and encryption method used to sign the token:
``` { typ: "JWT", alg: "RS256", x5t: "GvnPApfWMdLRi8PDmisFn7bprKg" } ```
The `alg` claim indicates the algorithm that was used to sign the token, while the `kid` or `x5t` claims indicate the particular public key that was used to sign the token.

trans-unit.source: At any given point in time, the v2.0 endpoint may sign an id_token using any one of a certain set of public-private key pairs.
trans-unit.target: At any given point in time, the v2.0 endpoint may sign an id_token using any one of a certain set of public-private key pairs.

trans-unit.source: The v2.0 endpoint rotates the possible set of keys on a periodic basis, so your app should be written to handle those key changes automatically.
trans-unit.target: The v2.0 endpoint rotates the possible set of keys on a periodic basis, so your app should be written to handle those key changes automatically.

trans-unit.source: A reasonable frequency to check for updates to the public keys used by the v2.0 endpoint is about 24 hours.
trans-unit.target: A reasonable frequency to check for updates to the public keys used by the v2.0 endpoint is about 24 hours.

trans-unit.source:
You can acquire the signing key data necessary to validate the signature by using the OpenID Connect metadata document located at:
`https://login.microsoftonline.com/common/v2.0/.well-known/openid-configuration`
This metadata document is a JSON object containing several useful pieces of information, such as the location of the various endpoints required for performing OpenID Connect authentication.
trans-unit.target:
You can acquire the signing key data necessary to validate the signature by using the OpenID Connect metadata document located at:
`https://login.microsoftonline.com/common/v2.0/.well-known/openid-configuration`
This metadata document is a JSON object containing several useful pieces of information, such as the location of the various endpoints required for performing OpenID Connect authentication.

trans-unit.source: It also includes a `jwks_uri`, which gives the location of the set of public keys used to sign tokens.
trans-unit.target: It also includes a `jwks_uri`, which gives the location of the set of public keys used to sign tokens.

trans-unit.source:
That location is provided below, but it is best to fetch that location dynamically by using the metadata document and parsing out the `jwks_uri`:
`https://login.microsoftonline.com/common/discovery/v2.0/keys`
The JSON document located at this url contains all of the public key information in use at that particular moment in time.

That location is provided below, but it is best to fetch that location dynamically by using the metadata document and parsing out the `jwks_uri`:

trans-unit.source: Your app can use the `kid` or `x5t` claims in the JWT header to select which public key in this document has been used to sign a particular token.

trans-unit.target: Validating the Claims When your app receives an id_token upon user sign-in, it should also perform a few checks against the claims in the id_token.

trans-unit.source:
These include:
- The **Audience** claim - to verify that the id_token was intended to be given to your app.
trans-unit.target:
These include:

trans-unit.source: - The **Issued At** and **Expiration Time** claims - to verify that the id_token has not expired.

trans-unit.source: - The **Issuer** claim - to verify that the token was indeed issued to your app by the v2.0 endpoint.
